GermlineClassification.ReviewStatus: criteria provided, multiple submitters, no conflicts

AttributeSet.Attribute: Angelman syndrome (AS) is characterized by severe developmental delay or intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, gait ataxia and/or tremulousness of the limbs, and unique behavior with an apparent happy demeanor that includes frequent laughing, smiling, and excitability. Microcephaly and seizures are also common. Developmental delays are first noted at around age six months; however, the unique clinical features of AS do not become manifest until after age one year.
AS is caused by disruption of maternally imprinted UBE3A located within the 15q11.2-q13 Angelman syndrome/Prader-Willi syndrome (AS/PWS) region.

ClinVarAccession.SubmitterName: Clinical Molecular Genetics Laboratory, Johns Hopkins All Children's Hospital

ObservedIn.Comment: Angelman syndrome family mutation UBE3A gene.
Features suggestive of Angelman syndrome. Sister similarly affected.
Testing for familial mutation for the clinical diagnosis of Angelman Syndrome.
Angelman syndrome family mutation UBE3A gene.

Classification.Comment: The UBE3A c.1811_1812delGT variant is predicted to result in a frameshift and premature protein termination (p.Cys604Tyrfs*23). This variant has been reported as pathogenic in individuals with neurological and epilepsy phenotypes. In at least one study, the variant was reported to occur de novo (Table S3, Helbig et al. 2016. PubMed ID: 26795593; Ganapathy et al. 2019. PubMed ID: 31069529). Frameshift variants upstream and downstream of this position have also been reported as pathogenic in individuals with Angelman syndrome phenotypes (HGMD, Human Gene Mutation Database). To our knowledge, this variant has not been reported in the literature or in a large population database (http://gnomad.broadinstitute.org), indicating this variant is rare. Taken together, this variant is interpreted as pathogenic.
